title: Yuknoom Chʼeen I
text:
Yuknoom Chʼeen I was the first known <a href="Maya%20civilization">Maya</a> <a href="Ajaw">king</a> of <a href="Calakmul">the Kaan Kingdom</a>. He was maybe a father of King <a href="Tuun%20K%CA%BCab%CA%BC%20Hix">Tuun Kʼabʼ Hix</a>.
Identity.
Although nineteen <a href="Maya%20rulers">Kaan kings</a> are listed on the <a href="Dynasty">Dynastic</a> <a href="Vase">Vase</a>s, some with the names of known historical rulers, clear discrepancies in their accession dates make it uncertain whether the nineteen names are to be considered historical or <a href="Mythological%20king">legendary</a>. Thus Yuknoom Chʼeen can be said to be the first known, clearly historical ruler of Kaan.
That kingdom's location in Yuknoom Chʼeen's time — roughly the years around AD 500 — is not certain; although <a href="Calakmul">Calakmul</a> is known to have been the <a href="Capital%20city">capital</a> in the <a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Late Classic</a>, there is a reason to doubt that this was the case earlier. <a href="Dzibanche">Dzibanche</a> emerges as a strong possibility for the previous center because Yuknoom Chʼeen is repeatedly named there on a sculptured "captive stairway". Although this monument's interpretation hinges on a single problematic <a href="Maya%20script">glyph</a>, it is likely that Yuknoom Chʼeen was a ruler of Dzibanche and the <a href="Hostage">captives</a> were his trophies.
